item.title: The Yellow Christ by Paul Gauguin (1889)
item.description: The Yellow Christ is a pivotal piece in post-Impressionism, showcasing Gauguin's innovative use of color and symbolic representation. The painting presents a stark contrast between the vibrant yellow of Christ and the somber environment surrounding Him. This work marks a departure from naturalism, embracing an emotional intensity and spiritual symbolism that influenced the Symbolist movement and modern art. Gauguin's decision to depict Christ with non-naturalistic hues challenges traditional religious iconography and evokes a deeper exploration of faith and humanity.

item.title: The Last Supper by Leonardo da Vinci (1495-1498)
item.description: Leonardo da Vinci's 'The Last Supper' is one of the most significant artworks in Western art history, depicting the final meal shared by Jesus and his apostles before his crucifixion. This mural, located in the refectory of the Convent of Santa Maria delle Grazie in Milan, demonstrates revolutionary techniques in composition and perspective, influencing countless artists. Its emotional depth, innovative use of space, and masterful rendering of human expressions mark it as a pivotal work that continues to inspire and awe audiences centuries later.

item.title: The Treachery of Images by René Magritte (1928-1929)
item.description: This artwork famously challenges viewers' perceptions of reality and representation. By declaring 'Ceci n'est pas une pipe' ('This is not a pipe') beneath an image of a pipe, Magritte emphasizes the disparity between an object and its depiction, provoking thought about language, art, and interpretation. This breakthrough idea has influenced not only art but philosophy and literature, ultimately reshaping how we understand images in modern culture.

item.description: Marcel Duchamp's 'Fountain' is a groundbreaking work in the realm of conceptual art. It sparked debates about what constitutes 'art' that are still relevant today, leading to the development of movements like Dada and later conceptual art.
